SPECIAL MAY FESTIVALS:

SRI KURMA JAYANTI (May 1):
Birthday of Lord Kurma (tortoise avatar of Vishnu). Second avatar that appeared during the churning of the ocean (Samudra Manthan) to support Mount Mandara.

SRI ANNAMACHARYA JAYANTI (May 1):
Birth anniversary of Sri Tallapaka Annamacharya (1408-1503), the great composer of devotional songs (sankirtanas) dedicated to Lord Venkateswara. Composed over 32,000 devotional compositions.

SRI HANUMAN JAYANTI (May 11):
Birthday of Lord Hanuman, the devoted servant of Lord Rama. Special celebrations with prayers, bhajans, and reading of Hanuman Chalisa. Fasting and special poojas observed.

SRI SANISCHARA JAYANTI (May 16):
Birth anniversary of Lord Shani (Saturn deity). Special prayers offered to alleviate Saturn-related difficulties. Occurs on Amavasya, making it doubly significant.

NAMMAZHWAR TIRUNAKSHATRAM (May 29):
Birth star of Nammazhwar (Sadagopan), one of the twelve Alvars and the greatest Vaishnava saint poet. Composed Thiruvaimozhi, considered the Tamil Veda.

ADHIKA MAASA (LEAP MONTH):
May 16 - June 13 is Adhika Jyeshta Maasa (extra/leap month added to align lunar and solar calendars). During Adhika Maasa:
- Regular festivals are generally not celebrated
- Auspicious ceremonies like weddings are avoided
- Good time for spiritual practices, meditation, charity
- This is why May has two Purnimas

SPECIAL NOVEMBER FESTIVALS:

NARAKA CHATURDASI (Nov 7):
Day before Deepavali. Celebrates Krishna's victory over demon Narakasura. Early morning oil bath before sunrise.

DEEPAVALI / DIWALI (Nov 8):
Festival of Lights. Most widely celebrated Hindu festival. Symbolizes victory of light over darkness, good over evil. Lighting of diyas (lamps), fireworks, exchange of sweets, Lakshmi puja, and family gatherings.

NAGA CHATURTHI / NAGULA CHAVITI (Nov 12):
Telugu festival for serpent worship. Women pray for well-being of brothers.

SRI MANAVALA MAHAMUNI TIRUNAKSHATRAM (Nov 12):
Birth star of Manavala Mamuni, important Sri Vaishnava acharya.

SRI VISHVAKSENA JAYANTI (Nov 14):
Birthday of Vishvaksena, commander-in-chief of Lord Vishnu's army. Worshiped as remover of obstacles in Vaishnavism.

SRI SKANDA SHASHTI (Nov 14):
Sixth day festival dedicated to Lord Murugan (Skanda). Celebrates his victory over demon Surapadman.

SRI TULASI KALYANAM (Nov 21):
Divine wedding of Tulasi (sacred basil plant) with Lord Vishnu/Shaligrama. Marks end of monsoon season and beginning of wedding season.

KARTIKA PURNIMA (Nov 23):
Full moon of Kartika month. Very auspicious for lighting lamps. Also called Tripuri Purnima.

KARTIKA DEEPAM (Nov 23):
Festival of lamps on Kartika Purnima. Especially significant in South India.

KARTIKA SOMAVARA (Throughout November):
Mondays in Kartika month are specially auspicious for Lord Shiva worship. Special Siva Abhishekams performed.

SPECIAL OCTOBER FESTIVALS:

MAHALAYA AMAVASYA (Oct 10):
Most important day of Pitru Paksha. Final day for performing Shraddha (ancestral rites). Marks beginning of Navaratri. Tarpana offerings made to ancestors.

SARANNAVARATRI / NAVARATRI (Oct 11-20):
Nine-night festival worshiping Divine Mother in her various forms:
- Days 1-3: Goddess Durga (destroyer of evil)
- Days 4-6: Goddess Lakshmi (bestower of wealth)
- Days 7-9: Goddess Saraswati (giver of knowledge)

SARASWATI PUJA (Oct 16):
Seventh day of Navaratri dedicated to Goddess Saraswati. Books and musical instruments are worshiped. Auspicious for starting education.

DURGASHTAMI (Oct 18):
Eighth day of Navaratri. Most important day for Durga worship. Special poojas and kumari (young girl) worship.

MAHARNAVAMI / AYUDHA PUJA (Oct 19):
Ninth day - worship of weapons, tools, and vehicles. In South India, all implements of livelihood are worshiped.

VIJAYA DASAMI (Oct 20):
Victory of Goddess Durga over demon Mahishasura. Also celebrates Lord Rama's victory over Ravana. Most auspicious day to begin new ventures, education, and learning.

SPECIAL SEPTEMBER FESTIVALS:

SRI KRISHNASHTAMI (Sep 4):
Birthday of Lord Krishna, eighth avatar of Vishnu. Celebrated with fasting, midnight poojas (birth time), devotional singing, and enactment of Krishna's life events. Dahi Handi celebrations.

SRI VINAYAKA CHATURTHI (Sep 14):
Ganesh Chaturthi - Birthday of Lord Ganesha. Ten-day festival with installation of Ganesha idols, daily poojas, and cultural programs.

SRI VINAYAKA NIMAJJANAM (Sep 19):
Ganesh Visarjan - Immersion of Ganesha idols marking the end of Ganesh Chaturthi celebrations.

SRI VENKATESWARA SWAMY JAYANTI (Sep 22):
Birthday of Lord Venkateswara. Special celebrations at all Venkateswara temples.

SRI VEDANTA DESIKAR TIRUNAKSHATRAM (Sep 22):
Birth star of Sri Vedanta Desika, great Vaishnava philosopher and poet (1268-1369).

PAVITROTSAVAM (Sep 24-27):
Important temple festival for purification and renewal. "Pavitra" means sacred thread.
- Ankurarpanam (Sep 24): Ceremonial planting
- Pavitra Samarpana (Sep 25): Offering of sacred threads
- Shanti Kalyanam (Sep 27): Divine wedding concluding the festival

MAHALAYA PAKSHAM (Starting Sep 27):
Fifteen-day period for ancestral rites (Pitru Paksha). Hindus perform Shraddha ceremonies for deceased ancestors. Ends with Mahalaya Amavasya (Oct 10).

Date: Thursday, December 4, 2025

DECEMBER 15TH, 2025 - DHANURMASAM BEGINS
Date: Monday, December 15, 2025
Duration: December 15, 2025 - January 14, 2026 (30 days)

Also Known As: Dhanur Maasa, Auspicious Month for Lord Vishnu
DECEMBER 25, 2025 - CHRISTMAS
Date: Thursday, December 25, 2025
Tithi: Saptami
DECEMBER 30, 2025 - SRI VAIKUNTA EKADASI
Date: Tuesday, December 30, 2025
Tithi: Dwadashi (Ekadasi on Dec 29)
Significance: MOST AUSPICIOUS EKADASI OF THE YEAR
Temple Celebration: Grand celebration with extended hours
5:30 AM- Thirupalliyezhuchi Uttara Dwara Pooja
	Vaikunta Natha Alankaara Darshanam
Vishnusahasranam parayanam every hour 7 am -5 pm
6:00pm Swarna pushparchana
Swarna puspharchana -$51,
Vaikunta dwara pooja -$51,Vishesha archana -$31
Grand sponsor -$116
SIGNIFICANCE:
Vaikunta Ekadasi is the most important Ekadasi for Vaishnavites. According to Hindu belief, the gates of Vaikunta (Lord Vishnu's heavenly abode) open on this day, and devotees who worship Lord Vishnu with devotion can attain moksha (liberation).

SIGNIFICANCE:
Karthika Deepam is a festival of lights dedicated to Lord Shiva. It falls on the full moon day in the Tamil month of Karthikai (November-December). The festival celebrates the manifestation of Lord Shiva as an infinite column of light (Jyoti).
CELEBRATIONS:
- Lighting of lamps (deepas) throughout the temple
- Special abhishekam to Lord Shiva
- Deepa aradhana (lamp offering ceremony)
- Community gathering and prayers

Date: Monday, November 17, 2025
Day: Somavara (Monday)

NOVEMBER 27TH, 2025 - THANKSGIVING DAY
SIGNIFICANCE:
Tulasi Kalyanam (also called Tulasi Vivah) celebrates the sacred marriage of the holy Tulasi plant (Holy Basil) to Lord Vishnu in his Shaligram form. This marks the beginning of the Hindu wedding season and the end of the four-month Chaturmas period.
MYTHOLOGY:
According to Hindu scriptures, Tulasi Devi was a devoted woman named Vrinda who was transformed into the sacred Tulasi plant. Her marriage to Lord Vishnu is celebrated annually on this auspicious day.
TEMPLE CELEBRATIONS:
- Traditional wedding ceremony performed for Tulasi plant
- Tulasi Devi adorned as a bride
- Shaligram (form of Vishnu) as the groom
- Vedic mantras and traditional marriage rituals
- Circumambulation (pradakshina) around Tulasi
- Special prasadam distribution
DEVOTIONAL PRACTICE:
- Devotees can bring flowers, fruits for offering
- Participate in the marriage ceremony
- Seek blessings for their own marriages
- Water Tulasi plant as part of daily worship
SPIRITUAL BENEFITS:
- Blessings for married life
- Removal of obstacles in finding suitable match
- Spiritual purification
- Starting auspicious activities after Chaturmas
WHAT TO BRING:
- Flowers for decoration
- Fruits for offering
- Traditional wedding items (optional)
OCTOBER 2025 TEMPLE EVENTS & FESTIVALS

OCTOBER 1ST, 2025 - VIJAYA DASAMI
Date: Wednesday, October 1, 2025
Also Known As: Vijayadashami, Dussehra
Significance: Victory of good over evil
Day: 10th day of Navaratri festival
SIGNIFICANCE:
Vijaya Dasami celebrates the victory of Goddess Durga over the demon Mahishasura and Lord Rama's victory over Ravana. "Vijaya" means victory and "Dasami" means tenth day.
TWO MAJOR STORIES:
**Story 1 - Goddess Durga's Victory**:
After nine days of fierce battle during Navaratri, Goddess Durga finally defeated the buffalo demon Mahishasura on the tenth day, restoring peace to the heavens and earth.
**Story 2 - Lord Rama's Victory**:
Lord Rama defeated the demon king Ravana after a great battle, rescuing his wife Sita. This victory of dharma (righteousness) over adharma (evil) is celebrated as Dussehra.
TEMPLE CELEBRATIONS:
- Durga Puja and final day ceremonies
- Victory celebrations
- Distribution of prasadam
- Community gatherings
- Blessing of new ventures and tools
CULTURAL SIGNIFICANCE:
- Auspicious day to begin new learning
- Starting new ventures and businesses
- Children begin education (Vidyarambham)
- Worship of books, tools, instruments
DEVOTIONAL PRACTICES:
- Seeking blessings for success
- Performing Ayudha Puja (worship of instruments/tools)
- Charitable giving
- Family celebrations
SPIRITUAL BENEFITS:
- Victory over inner demons (anger, greed, ego)
- Blessings for new beginnings
- Courage and strength
- Success in endeavors

OCTOBER 2ND, 2025 - SRI VENKATESWARA JAYANTI
Date: Thursday, October 2, 2025
Also Known As: Venkateswara Jayanti, Lord Balaji's Birthday
Nakshatra: Revati (Lord Vishnu's birth star)
Temple Celebration: Grand celebrations, special abhishekam, Unjal Seva
SIGNIFICANCE:
Sri Venkateswara Jayanti commemorates the divine appearance of Lord Venkateswara (Lord Balaji) on earth. This is one of the most important festivals celebrated at all Venkateswara temples worldwide.
ABOUT LORD VENKATESWARA:
Lord Venkateswara is a manifestation of Lord Vishnu who incarnated on earth to save humanity from the trials and troubles of Kali Yuga. His main temple is at Tirumala-Tirupati, Andhra Pradesh, India.
UNJAL SEVA (SWING CEREMONY):
Special ceremony where Lord Venkateswara is placed on a beautifully decorated swing while devotees sing bhajans and devotional songs. This ceremony symbolizes the playful, loving nature of the Lord.
OCTOBER 4TH, 2025 - SRI VEDANTA DESIKAR THIRUNAKSHATRAM
Date: Saturday, October 4, 2025
Occasion: Birth anniversary of Sri Vedanta Desikan
Tradition: Sri Vaishnava Acharya commemoration
Nakshatra: Avittam (Dhanishta)
ABOUT SRI VEDANTA DESIKAN:
Sri Vedanta Desikan (1268-1369 CE) was one of the greatest Sri Vaishnava philosophers, poets, and scholars. He wrote over 100 works in Sanskrit, Tamil, and Prakrit covering philosophy, poetry, drama, and devotional literature.
SIGNIFICANCE:
- One of the most prominent Acharyas in Sri Vaishnava tradition
- Master of Vedanta philosophy
- Author of numerous devotional and philosophical works
- Established important principles of Vishishtadvaita
FAMOUS WORKS:
- Paduka Sahasram (1000 verses on Lord's sandals)
- Hamsa Sandesam
- Many philosophical treatises

OCTOBER 5TH, 2025 - UDAYASTAMANA SEVA / SANI TRAYODASI
Date: Sunday, October 5, 2025
Tithi: Trayodasi (13th day)
Observance: Special Shiva worship / Saturn appeasement
UDAYASTAMANA SEVA:
Special seva performed from sunrise to sunset for Lord Shiva, offering continuous worship throughout the day.
SANI TRAYODASI:
Day dedicated to appeasing Lord Shani (Saturn) to remove obstacles and difficulties caused by Saturn's influence in one's horoscope.

OCTOBER 9TH, 2025 - SRI VISHVAKSENA JAYANTI
Date: Thursday, October 9, 2025
Deity: Sri Vishvaksena (Commander-in-Chief of Lord Vishnu)
Tradition: Sri Vaishnava observance
ABOUT SRI VISHVAKSENA:
Sri Vishvaksena is the divine commander of Lord Vishnu's army and the leader of all devotees. He is worshipped at the beginning of all Vaishnava rituals as the one who removes obstacles.
SIGNIFICANCE:
- Commander of celestial armies
- Remover of obstacles in devotion
- First to be worshipped in temple rituals
- Guardian deity of devotees
TEMPLE OBSERVANCES:
- Special prayers and offerings
- Beginning all temple rituals with Vishvaksena vandanam
- Traditional worship ceremony
ROLE IN TEMPLE WORSHIP:
Every pooja at Vaishnava temples begins with prayers to Sri Vishvaksena, seeking his permission and blessings for smooth conduct of worship.

OCTOBER 16TH, 2025 - SANI TRAYODASI
Date: Thursday, October 16, 2025
Tithi: Trayodasi (13th day)
Observance: Saturn appeasement day
[Same significance as October 5th Sani Trayodasi]
This is the second Sani Trayodasi of the month, providing another opportunity for Saturn-related prayers and remedies.

OCTOBER 19TH, 2025 - NARAKA CHATURDASI
Date: Sunday, October 19, 2025
Tithi: Chaturdasi (14th day, one day before Amavasya)
Also Known As: Choti Diwali, Narak Chaturdashi
Celebration: Pre-Diwali celebrations
SIGNIFICANCE:
Naraka Chaturdasi celebrates Lord Krishna's victory over the demon Narakasura, who had imprisoned 16,000 women and stolen valuable possessions from gods.
THE STORY:
With the help of his wife Satyabhama, Lord Krishna defeated the demon king Narakasura, freed the imprisoned women, and restored peace. Before dying, Narakasura requested that his death anniversary be celebrated with lights and joy.
TEMPLE CELEBRATIONS:
- Pre-Diwali prayers
- Oil bath ceremony (Abhyanga Snan)
- Lighting of lamps
- Special abhishekam
- Preparation for main Diwali
TRADITIONAL PRACTICES:
- Early morning oil bath (Abhyanga Snan)
- Applying ubtan (herbal paste)
- Lighting diyas in evening
- Bursting firecrackers (traditional, if permitted)
- Preparing sweets
SPIRITUAL SIGNIFICANCE:
- Victory of good over evil
- Cleansing of sins
- Removal of darkness (ignorance)
- Preparation for spiritual illumination

OCTOBER 20TH, 2025 - DEEPAVALI / DIWALI
Date: Monday, October 20, 2025
Tithi: Amavasya (New Moon Day)
Significance: FESTIVAL OF LIGHTS - Major Hindu Festival
Duration: Main day of 5-day Diwali celebrations
SIGNIFICANCE:
Deepavali (Diwali) is one of the most important Hindu festivals, celebrating the victory of light over darkness, good over evil, and knowledge over ignorance.
FOUR MAJOR LEGENDS:
1. **Lord Rama's Return**: Return of Lord Rama to Ayodhya after 14 years of exile
2. **Goddess Lakshmi's Birth**: Emergence of Goddess Lakshmi during ocean churning
3. **Krishna vs Narakasura**: Lord Krishna's victory over demon
4. **Pandavas' Return**: Return of Pandavas after 13 years of exile

OCTOBER 26TH, 2025 - SRI MANAVALA MAHAMUNI THIRUNAKSHATRAM
Date: Sunday, October 26, 2025
Occasion: Birth anniversary of Sri Manavala Mamunigal
Tradition: Sri Vaishnava Acharya commemoration
Nakshatra: Mula
ABOUT SRI MANAVALA MAMUNIGAL:
Sri Manavala Mamunigal (1370-1443 CE) was a prominent Sri Vaishnava Acharya and scholar who played a crucial role in spreading Sri Vaishnava philosophy in Tamil Nadu.
SIGNIFICANCE:
- Great exponent of Ramanuja's philosophy
- Author of numerous Tamil commentaries
- Reviver of Sri Vaishnava tradition
- Established important theological principles
TEMPLE OBSERVANCES:
- Special prayers and homage
- Reading of his compositions
- Discourse on his teachings
- Traditional worship ceremony
- Guru vandanam
FAMOUS WORKS:
- Commentaries on Divya Prabandham
- Upadesa Ratnamaalai
- Artha Panchakam
- Many devotional compositions

OCTOBER 27TH, 2025 - SRI SKANDA SHASHTI
Date: Monday, October 27, 2025
Tithi: Shashti (6th day)
Deity: Lord Murugan (Skanda, Kartikeya)
Significance: Victory of Lord Murugan over demon Surapadman
ABOUT THE FESTIVAL:
Skanda Shashti commemorates the six-day battle between Lord Murugan (son of Lord Shiva) and the demon Surapadman, which culminated in the demon's defeat on the sixth day.
THE STORY:
The demon Surapadman terrorized the gods and took over the heavens. The gods prayed to Lord Shiva, who created Lord Murugan from his third eye to destroy the demon. After six days of fierce battle, Lord Murugan defeated Surapadman.

APRIL 1, 2026 - SRI SATYANARAYANA SWAMY POOJA & VRATHAM
Date: Wednesday, April 1, 2026
Tithi: Purnima (Full Moon)
Temple Celebration: Special pooja and vratam at 6:30 PM

APRIL 14, 2026 - TAMIL NEW YEAR / VISHU
Date: Tuesday, April 14, 2026
Tithi: Trayodasi
Temple Celebration: New Year prayers and blessings
TAMIL NEW YEAR SIGNIFICANCE:
The Tamil New Year marks the first day of the Tamil month Chithirai. It's celebrated with special prayers, new clothes, and traditional foods.
VISHU SIGNIFICANCE:
Vishu is the New Year celebration in Kerala. The festival begins with "Vishukkani" - the first auspicious sight of the year, which includes gold, flowers, fruits, rice, and a mirror arranged before an idol of Lord Krishna.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Vishukkani darshan (first auspicious sight)
- New clothes (Vishukodi)
- Bursting of firecrackers
- Special feast (Vishu Sadya)
- Giving gifts to children (Vishukaineettam)
- Temple visits for blessings

APRIL 19, 2026 - AKSHAYA TRITIYA
Date: Sunday, April 19, 2026
Tithi: Tritiya
Also on this day: Sri Shirdi Sai Baba / Raghavendra Swamy Abhishekam
Temple Celebration: Special prayers for prosperity
SIGNIFICANCE:
Akshaya Tritiya is one of the most auspicious days in the Hindu calendar. "Akshaya" means imperishable or eternal. Any activity started on this day is believed to bring lasting prosperity and success. It's considered self-auspicious (Swayam Siddha Muhurta), requiring no additional astrological considerations.
MYTHOLOGICAL SIGNIFICANCE:
- Birth of Lord Parasurama (6th avatar of Vishnu)
- Treta Yuga began on this day
- Kubera received his wealth on this day
- Ved Vyasa and Lord Ganesha began writing Mahabharata
CELEBRATIONS:
- Buying gold and starting new ventures
- Charity and donations (highly meritorious)
- Starting new businesses
- Performing weddings
- Initiating children into education
- Planting trees
AUSPICIOUS FOR:
- Buying property
- Making investments
- Starting construction
- Beginning spiritual practices
- All types of poojas and yagnas

APRIL 21, 2026 - SRI SANKARACHARYA JAYANTI
Date: Tuesday, April 21, 2026
Tithi: Panchami
Temple Celebration: Special prayers and discourses
SIGNIFICANCE:
Sri Adi Shankaracharya Jayanti celebrates the birth anniversary of Adi Shankaracharya (788-820 CE), one of the greatest philosophers and theologians in Hindu history. He established the Advaita Vedanta philosophy and revived Hinduism during a period of decline.
CONTRIBUTIONS:
- Established four major mathas (monasteries) across India:
  * Sringeri Mutt (South)
  * Dwaraka Mutt (West)
  * Puri Mutt (East)
  * Jyotir Math (North)
- Composed numerous hymns (stotras)
- Wrote commentaries on Upanishads, Brahma Sutras, and Bhagavad Gita
- Unified Hindu thought and practices
CELEBRATIONS:
- Special poojas and prayers
- Reading of Shankaracharya's works
- Philosophical discourses
- Bhajan and kirtan
- Charity and anna danam

APRIL 22, 2026 - SRI RAMANUJA JAYANTI
Date: Wednesday, April 22, 2026
Tithi: Shashti
Temple Celebration: Special celebrations for Ramanuja
SIGNIFICANCE:
Sri Ramanuja Jayanti celebrates the birth of Sri Ramanujacharya (1017-1137 CE), the great Vaishnava philosopher and proponent of Vishishtadvaita (qualified non-dualism). He revolutionized temple worship and made it accessible to all.
CONTRIBUTIONS:
- Systematized Sri Vaishnavism
- Wrote Sri Bhashya (commentary on Brahma Sutras)
- Organized temple worship traditions
- Established equality in temple access
- Composed important Vaishnava texts
CELEBRATIONS:
- Special abhishekam to Sri Ramanuja's vigraha
- Reading of Ramanuja's works
- Lectures on Vishishtadvaita philosophy
- Prasadam distribution
- Community prayers

APRIL 30, 2026 - SRI NRUSIMHA JAYANTI
Date: Thursday, April 30, 2026
Tithi: Chaturdasi
Temple Celebration: Grand celebration with special abhishekams
SIGNIFICANCE:
Sri Nrusimha (Narasimha) Jayanti celebrates the birth of Lord Narasimha, the fourth avatar of Lord Vishnu. Lord Narasimha appeared as half-man, half-lion to protect his devotee Prahlada and destroy the demon Hiranyakashipu who could not be killed by man or animal, inside or outside, day or night.
STORY:
Prahlada, a devotee of Vishnu, was tortured by his demon father Hiranyakashipu for his devotion. When the demon challenged Vishnu's omnipresence, Narasimha emerged from a pillar at twilight (neither day nor night) and killed him on a threshold (neither inside nor outside) with his claws (neither weapon nor hand).
CELEBRATIONS:
- Special Narasimha abhishekam
- Reading of Prahlada Charitram
- Recitation of Narasimha mantras
- Offering of butter and curd rice
- Narasimha homam for protection
- All-night bhajan in some temples
SPIRITUAL SIGNIFICANCE:
- Protection of devotees
- Destruction of ego and evil
- Victory of devotion over tyranny
- Divine intervention in impossible situations

AUGUST 6, 2026 - ADI KRITTIKA
Date: Thursday, August 6, 2026
Tithi: Dasami
Nakshatra: Krittika
Temple Celebration: Special Murugan pooja
SIGNIFICANCE:
Adi Krittika is a Tamil festival dedicated to Lord Murugan (Karthikeya), celebrated when Krittika nakshatra falls in the Tamil month of Adi (mid-July to mid-August). Krittika is the birth star of Lord Murugan.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Special abhishekam to Lord Murugan
- Offering of kavadi (burden carrying)
- Temple processions
- Singing of Tamil devotional songs
- Distribution of prasadam

AUGUST 11, 2026 - SRI RAGHAVENDRA SWAMY ARADHANA
Date: Tuesday, August 11, 2026
Tithi: Amavasya (New Moon)
Temple Celebration: Special commemoration
SIGNIFICANCE:
Sri Raghavendra Swamy Aradhana commemorates the day when Sri Raghavendra Swamy entered Brindavan (living samadhi) in 1671 at Mantralayam. This is one of the most important festivals for followers of the Madhwa (Dvaita) tradition.
SRI RAGHAVENDRA SWAMY:
- Great saint and philosopher of 17th century
- Composed numerous works on Dvaita philosophy
- Known for miraculous powers and compassion
- Established at Mantralayam, Andhra Pradesh
- Believed to be in perpetual meditation in Brindavan
CELEBRATIONS:
- Special abhishekam to Raghavendra Swamy
- Reading of his works and life story
- Offering of sweet payasam (his favorite)
- All-day bhajan and kirtan
- Distribution of prasadam
- Charity and feeding the poor

AUGUST 14, 2026 - SRI ANDAL JAYANTI
Date: Friday, August 14, 2026
Tithi: Dwitiya/Tritiya
Nakshatra: Purvaphalguni
Also on this day: Sri Andal Abhishekam
Temple Celebration: Grand birthday celebration
SIGNIFICANCE:
Sri Andal Jayanti celebrates the birth of Sri Andal (Goda Devi), the only female among the twelve Alvars (Vaishnava saint poets). She was found as a baby under a Tulasi plant by Periyalvar in Srivilliputhur, Tamil Nadu. Andal is considered an incarnation of Bhudevi (Mother Earth).
ANDAL'S CONTRIBUTIONS:
- Composed Thiruppavai (30 verses)
- Composed Nachiyar Thirumozhi (143 verses)
- Exemplifies pure devotion (Madhurya Bhakti)
- Represents devotee's longing for union with divine
- Her works are recited daily in Vaishnava temples
CELEBRATIONS:
- Special alankaram (decoration) to Andal
- Recitation of Thiruppavai
- Goda Kalyanam (divine wedding reenactment)
- Flower decorations
- Cultural programs depicting Andal's life
- Distribution of prasadam
SPIRITUAL SIGNIFICANCE:
Andal's life teaches complete surrender to God and the path of devotional love (Bhakti).

AUGUST 16, 2026 - GARUDA PANCHAMI / NAGA PANCHAMI
Date: Sunday, August 16, 2026
Tithi: Panchami/Shashti
Also on this day: Sri Shirdi Sai Baba Abhishekam
Temple Celebration: Dual celebration
GARUDA PANCHAMI SIGNIFICANCE:
Honors Lord Garuda, the divine vehicle (vahana) of Lord Vishnu. Garuda, the king of birds, symbolizes power, devotion, and the ability to overcome obstacles.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Special Garuda pooja
- Recitation of Garuda Purana
- Prayers for protection from snake bites
- Offering of special naivedyam
NAGA PANCHAMI SIGNIFICANCE:
Festival dedicated to serpent deities (Nagas). Snakes are worshiped as symbols of fertility, protection, and cosmic energy. In Hindu mythology, snakes have divine significance.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Worship of snake idols or pictures
- Offering milk to snakes (traditional)
- Prayers for protection from snake bites
- Women tie sacred threads for brothers' protection
- Drawing snake images with turmeric and kumkum

AUGUST 21, 2026 - SRI VARALAKSHMI VRATAM
Date: Friday, August 21, 2026
Tithi: Ekadasi
Temple Celebration: Special Lakshmi pooja for women
SIGNIFICANCE:
Sri Varalakshmi Vratam is one of the most important festivals for married Hindu women, primarily observed in South India. Women pray to Goddess Lakshmi (consort of Lord Vishnu) for the well-being, prosperity, and long life of their husbands and families.
LEGEND:
Based on a story where Goddess Parvati advised a devoted woman named Charumathi to worship Goddess Varalakshmi on this day, promising fulfillment of wishes.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Women observe fast (complete or partial)
- Special kalasam (sacred pot) installation
- Worshiping Varalakshmi (boon-granting Lakshmi)
- Tying of sacred thread (kappu/raksha)
- Offering traditional naivedyam
- Inviting married women (Sumangalis)
- Exchanging gifts and betel leaves
- Seeking blessings for family prosperity
PREPARATIONS:
- Decorating pooja room elaborately
- Creating special rangoli/kolam
- Preparing traditional sweets and savories
- Dressing in traditional attire and jewelry

AUGUST 26, 2026 - RIGVEDA UPAKARMA
Date: Wednesday, August 26, 2026
Tithi: Prathama
Temple Celebration: Sacred thread ceremony for Rigvedis
SIGNIFICANCE:
Upakarma is the annual ritual of changing the sacred thread (Yajnopavita) and beginning new study of Vedas. Rigveda Upakarma is observed by Brahmins following the Rigveda tradition.
RITUALS:
- Holy bath in sacred waters or rivers
- Removal of old sacred thread
- Wearing new sacred thread with Vedic chants
- Performing rituals with family priest
- Beginning of Vedic study for the year

AUGUST 27, 2026 - YAJURVEDA UPAKARMA / AVANI AVITTAM / RAKHI PURNIMA / LUNAR ECLIPSE
Date: Thursday, August 27, 2026
Tithi: Dwitiya (after Purnima)
Also Known As: Raksha Bandhan
Also on this day: Sri Satyanarayana Pooja & Vratham
Temple Celebration: Multiple auspicious observances with eclipse rituals
YAJURVEDA UPAKARMA / AVANI AVITTAM SIGNIFICANCE:
Sacred thread changing ceremony for Yajurvedi Brahmins - the most widely observed Upakarma. "Avani Avittam" is the Tamil name for this festival.
RITUALS:
- Holy bath before sunrise
- Wearing new sacred thread
- Kamokarsheet mantra (seeking forgiveness for sins)
- Vedic study begins
- Family gatherings and feast
RAKSHA BANDHAN / RAKHI PURNIMA SIGNIFICANCE:
Festival celebrating the bond between brothers and sisters. Sisters tie a sacred thread (rakhi) on their brothers' wrists, and brothers pledge protection and give gifts.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Sisters tie rakhi with prayers
- Brothers give gifts and promise protection
- Family gatherings
- Exchange of sweets
- Priests tie rakhi on devotees' wrists for protection
LUNAR ECLIPSE:
Partial/Total Lunar Eclipse visible from 9:33 PM to 1:51 AM
ECLIPSE OBSERVANCES:
- Bath before and after eclipse
- Chanting of mantras during eclipse
- No eating during eclipse period
- Special prayers and charity
- Temples perform special rituals
COMBINED SIGNIFICANCE:
This rare combination of Upakarma, Rakhi, and Lunar Eclipse makes this day extremely powerful for spiritual practices and renewal.

DECEMBER 16, 2026 - DHANURMASAM BEGINS
Date: Wednesday, December 16, 2026
Duration: December 16, 2026 - January 14, 2027 (30 days)
Tithi: Ashtami
Also Known As: Dhanur Maasa, Dhanush Maasam
Temple Celebration: Special month-long observances begin
SIGNIFICANCE:
Dhanurmasam is considered the most auspicious month for worshiping Lord Vishnu. "Dhanur" refers to the Dhanus (Sagittarius) constellation, through which the sun travels during this month. This month is mentioned in sacred texts like Padma Purana and Bhagavad Gita.
SPIRITUAL IMPORTANCE:
- Most sacred month for Vishnu devotees
- Equivalent to performing thousand Ashwamedha Yagnas
- Sins are washed away by worship during this month
- Path to moksha (liberation)
- Lord Krishna himself recommends this month in Bhagavad Gita
DAILY OBSERVANCES:
- Waking before sunrise
- Holy bath before dawn
- Suprabhatam (waking the Lord) seva
- Reading/chanting Bhagavad Gita
- Vishnu Sahasranama recitation
- Special archanas and abhishekams
- Lighting lamps in temples
- Charity and feeding the poor
TEMPLE SCHEDULE DURING DHANURMASAM:
- Early morning Suprabhatam (before sunrise)
- Special Vishnu poojas throughout the day
- Daily abhishekams
- Gita parayana (reading)
- Evening aarti and bhajans
DEVOTEE PRACTICES:
- Many observe fasting
- Vegetarian diet strictly followed
- Avoiding certain foods (varies by tradition)
- Increased temple visits
- Daily prayers and meditation
- Acts of charity
PROHIBITED DURING DHANURMASAM:
- Weddings and auspicious ceremonies
- Hair cutting
- Celebrations and festivities
- New ventures
BENEFITS OF DHANURMASAM WORSHIP:
- Spiritual purification
- Removal of sins
- Blessings for prosperity
- Protection from difficulties
- Progress on path to moksha

DECEMBER 20, 2026 - SRI VAIKUNTA EKADASI
Date: Sunday, December 20, 2026
Tithi: Ekadasi (on Dec 19-20)
Also on this day: Sri Venkateswara Abhishekam
Temple Celebration: MOST IMPORTANT EKADASI OF THE YEAR - Grand celebration
SIGNIFICANCE:
Sri Vaikunta Ekadasi is the most sacred and important Ekadasi of the entire year for Vaishnavites. "Vaikunta" is the heavenly abode of Lord Vishnu. It is believed that the gates of Vaikunta (Vaikunta Dwaram/Swarga Vathil) open on this day, and devotees who worship Lord Vishnu with devotion can attain moksha (liberation).
Also known as:
- Mukkoti Ekadasi (Ekadasi worth three crores)
- Swarga Vathil Ekadasi (Gate of Heaven Ekadasi)
MYTHOLOGICAL SIGNIFICANCE:
According to legend, a demon named Muran was terrorizing the worlds. Lord Vishnu's divine energy emerged as Ekadasi Devi and destroyed the demon. Pleased with her, Vishnu declared that those who fast on this day would reach Vaikunta.
SPIRITUAL IMPORTANCE:
- Opening of Vaikunta Dwaram (Heaven's gate)
- Path to liberation (moksha)
- Purification of all sins
- Equivalent to visiting all holy places
- Most auspicious day in the year for Vaishnavites
OBSERVANCES:
- Complete fasting (no food or water) by strict observers
- Partial fast (fruits and milk) by others
- Breaking fast only after sunrise on Dwadasi
- All-night vigil (jagaran) in some temples
- Reading of Vaikunta Gadyam
- Recitation of Vishnu Sahasranama
- Singing Vishnu bhajans and stotras
TEMPLE CELEBRATIONS:
- Opening of Vaikunta Dwaram (special decorated door)
- Devotees pass through the Vaikunta Dwaram
- Special abhishekams throughout the day
- Elaborate alankaram (decoration) to Lord Vishnu
- Processions with deity
- All-day bhajans and kirtans
- Distribution of special prasadam
- Extended temple hours
SPECIAL RITUALS:
- Snapana Tirumanjanam (sacred bath to deity)
- Offering of Tulasi leaves
- Lighting of lamps
- Reading of Bhagavad Gita
- Parayana (recitation) of sacred texts
BREAKING THE FAST:

Fast is broken on Dwadasi (next day) after sunrise with special prasadam.
COMBINED SIGNIFICANCE:
Vaikunta Ekadasi falling during Dhanurmasam makes it exceptionally powerful and meritorious. This is the holiest day of Dhanurmasam.

FEBRUARY 2026 EVENTS & FESTIVALS

FEBRUARY 1, 2026 - TAIPOOSAM
Date: Sunday, February 1, 2026
Tithi: Purnima (Full Moon)
Nakshatra: Pushyami
Also on this day: Sri Siva Abhishekam
SIGNIFICANCE:
Taipoosam (or Thaipusam) is a Tamil festival dedicated to Lord Murugan (Subramanya), the son of Lord Shiva. It celebrates the victory of good over evil and commemorates the day when Goddess Parvati gave the divine spear (Vel) to Lord Murugan to defeat the demon Surapadman. The festival occurs when the Pushya Nakshatra coincides with the full moon in the Tamil month of Thai.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Special abhishekam to Lord Murugan
- Kavadi (burden) carrying by devotees
- Fasting and prayers
- Processions with Lord Murugan's idol
- Recitation of Murugan songs and hymns
- Milk abhishekam
SPIRITUAL SIGNIFICANCE:
- Represents triumph of light over darkness
- Devotees undertake penances and vows
- Seeking blessings for strength and courage

FEBRUARY 14, 2026 - SANI TRAYODASI
Date: Saturday, February 14, 2026
Tithi: Trayodasi
Also on this day: Sri Venkateswara Kalyanam
SIGNIFICANCE:
Sani Trayodasi occurs when Trayodasi (13th lunar day) falls on Saturday (Sani-vara). This is considered highly auspicious for prayers to Lord Shani (Saturn deity). Worshiping on this day is believed to alleviate Saturn-related difficulties and bring relief from obstacles.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Special Shani pooja
- Offering of black sesame seeds and oil
- Lighting oil lamps
- Charity to the needy
- Recitation of Shani mantras
OBSERVANCES:
Devotees visit Shani temples, offer prayers, and perform rituals to appease Lord Shani.

FEBRUARY 15, 2026 - MAHA SIVARATRI
Date: Sunday/Monday, February 15-16, 2026
Tithi: Amavasya (New Moon)
Nakshatra: Sravana
Also on this day: Sri Shirdi Sai Baba / Raghavendra Swamy Abhishekam
Temple Celebration: All-night vigil with special poojas
SIGNIFICANCE:
Maha Sivaratri, "The Great Night of Shiva," is the most important festival dedicated to Lord Shiva. It marks the night when Lord Shiva performed the Tandava (cosmic dance of creation, preservation, and destruction). It is also celebrated as the night of Shiva's wedding to Goddess Parvati. This is the most sacred night for Shiva devotees.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Night-long vigil (jagaran)
- Four special abhishekams during the night (prahar poojas)
- Fasting (complete or with fruits/milk)
- Chanting "Om Namah Shivaya"
- Offering of bel leaves, milk, honey, water
- Rudra abhishekam
- Bilva archana (worship with bel leaves)
SPIRITUAL SIGNIFICANCE:
- Overcoming darkness and ignorance
- Union of Shiva and Shakti
- Path to moksha (liberation)
- Cleansing of sins
- Awakening of spiritual consciousness
OBSERVANCE:
Devotees stay awake all night, performing pooja at four different prahar (time periods). Many observe complete fast and break it only the next morning after sunrise.
SPECIAL RITUALS:
1. First Prahar (Evening): Abhishekam with milk
2. Second Prahar (Late night): Abhishekam with yogurt/curd
3. Third Prahar (Midnight): Abhishekam with ghee
4. Fourth Prahar (Pre-dawn): Abhishekam with honey

FEBRUARY 28, 2026 - SANI TRAYODASI

Also on this day: Sri Hanuman Abhishekam
SIGNIFICANCE:
Second Sani Trayodasi of the month. Auspicious for Lord Shani worship and prayers.

JANUARY 14, 2026 - MAKARA SANKRANTI / PONGAL / UTTARAYANAM BEGINS
Date: Wednesday, January 14, 2026
Tithi: Dwadasi
Also Known As: Thai Pongal, Harvest Festival

SIGNIFICANCE:
Makara Sankranti marks the sun's transition into Capricorn (Makara) and the beginning of Uttarayanam (sun's northward journey). This is one of the most auspicious periods in Hindu calendar. Pongal is the Tamil harvest festival celebrating the sun god and agricultural prosperity.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Surya (Sun) pooja
- Pongal cooking ceremony (rice boiled with milk and jaggery)
- Special kolam/rangoli decorations
- Distribution of pongal prasadam
- Cultural programs
- Community feast
UTTARAYANAM:
From this day until July, the sun travels north of the equator. This six-month period is considered highly auspicious for spiritual activities, weddings, and new beginnings. It is believed that those who depart during Uttarayanam attain moksha.

JANUARY 15, 2026 - KANUMA
Date: Thursday, January 15, 2026
Tithi: Trayodasi
Also Known As: Mattu Pongal (in Tamil tradition)
Also on this day: Sri Andal Abhishekam
SIGNIFICANCE:
Kanuma is the third day of Pongal celebrations, dedicated to cattle and farm animals. It's a day to thank and honor the animals that help in agriculture. Also known as Mattu Pongal (Cattle Pongal).
CELEBRATIONS:
- Decoration of cattle with flowers and turmeric
- Special prayers for livestock
- Community gatherings

SIGNIFICANCE:
Vasanta Panchami marks the beginning of spring season. Dedicated to Goddess Saraswati, the deity of knowledge, music, and arts. This is an auspicious day for starting education, learning music, or any new educational endeavor.
6:30 PM Sri Saraswati Devi Pooja, Saamoohika Aksharabhyasam

JANUARY 25, 2026 - RATHA SAPTAMI
Date: Sunday, January 25, 2026

SIGNIFICANCE:
Ratha Saptami celebrates the birthday of Sun God (Surya). The sun is believed to ride his chariot pulled by seven horses representing the seven days of the week and seven colors of light. This festival marks the change of season to spring and the northward journey of the sun.
9:00 AM :Suprabhatham followed by Arunam Parayanam

- Charitable activities

- Seven horses represent seven chakras in the body
- Symbolizes spiritual enlightenment
- Purifies mind and soul
- Removes sins and brings prosperity

JANUARY 28, 2026 - BHEESHMA EKADASI
Date: Wednesday, January 28, 2026
Tithi: Dwadasi (Ekadasi before it)
Also Known As: Magha Sukla Ekadasi
SIGNIFICANCE:
Bheeshma Ekadasi is associated with Bhishma Pitamaha from Mahabharata. On this day, Bhishma, lying on the bed of arrows, gave spiritual discourse to the Pandavas and Lord Krishna. Observing this Ekadasi is considered highly meritorious and removes all sins.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Fasting (complete or partial)
- Reading of Bhishma's teachings
- Special prayers to Lord Vishnu
- Charity and donations
- Visiting temples
OBSERVANCE:
Devotees fast on Ekadasi and break fast on Dwadasi after sunrise. Those unable to fast completely can take fruits and milk.

JULY 17, 2026 - DAKSHINAYANAM BEGINS
Date: Friday, July 17, 2026
Tithi: Panchami
Also on this day: Sri Andal Abhishekam
Temple Celebration: Special prayers marking sun's southward journey
SIGNIFICANCE:
Dakshinayanam marks the beginning of the sun's southward journey (from Cancer to Capricorn). This six-month period lasts until Makara Sankranti (mid-January). While Uttarayanam (northward) is considered auspicious for worldly activities, Dakshinayanam is considered ideal for spiritual practices, meditation, and inner growth.
SPIRITUAL SIGNIFICANCE:
- Time for spiritual pursuits
- Increased devotional activities
- Period for introspection and self-study
- Preparation for spiritual transformation
OBSERVANCES:
Special prayers and poojas are performed to seek blessings for the coming six months.

JULY 24, 2026 - TOLI EKADASI / SHAYANI EKADASI
Date: Friday, July 24, 2026
Tithi: Dwadasi (Ekadasi before it)
Also Known As: Ashadi Ekadasi, Padma Ekadasi
Temple Celebration: Special Ekadasi observances
SIGNIFICANCE:
Toli Ekadasi ("Toli" means "first" in Telugu) is the first Ekadasi of Dakshinayanam and marks a highly significant event in the Hindu calendar. Also called Shayani Ekadasi, it commemorates Lord Vishnu going into Yoga Nidra (divine sleep) for four months.
CHATURMASYA BEGINS:
This Ekadasi marks the beginning of Chaturmasya - a four-month period of increased spiritual activity lasting until Kartika Ekadasi (November). During this period:
- Lord Vishnu rests on Adishesha (cosmic serpent)
- No auspicious ceremonies like weddings
- Increased fasting and spiritual practices
- Special dietary restrictions (varies by tradition)
- Daily prayers and bhajans
CELEBRATIONS:
- Fasting on Ekadasi day
- Special Vishnu abhishekam
- Reading of Vishnu Sahasranama
- Tulasi (basil plant) worship
- All-night vigil in some temples
OBSERVANCES:
Devotees observe complete or partial fast. Some avoid rice, grains, or specific vegetables during the four-month period.

JULY 28, 2026 - GURU PURNIMA
Date: Tuesday, July 28, 2026
Tithi: Prathama (after Purnima)
Also Known As: Vyasa Purnima
Also on this day: Sri Satyanarayana Swamy Pooja & Vratham
Temple Celebration: Special prayers honoring gurus
SIGNIFICANCE:
Guru Purnima is dedicated to expressing gratitude to all spiritual and academic teachers (Gurus). "Guru" means one who removes darkness (ignorance) and brings light (knowledge). This festival honors Sage Veda Vyasa, compiler of the Vedas and author of Mahabharata.
SAGE VYASA:
- Compiled the four Vedas
- Wrote the Mahabharata
- Composed 18 Puranas
- Systematized Vedic knowledge
- Considered the Adi Guru (original teacher)
CELEBRATIONS:
- Guru pooja (worship of the teacher)
- Offering prayers to Vyasa
- Students honor their teachers
- Spiritual discourses
- Pada puja (washing guru's feet - symbolically)
- Gurudakshina (offering to the teacher)
- Reading of sacred texts
SPIRITUAL SIGNIFICANCE:
- Acknowledging the role of teachers in life
- Expressing gratitude for knowledge received
- Renewing commitment to learning
- Seeking blessings for spiritual progress
MODERN OBSERVANCE:
Students thank their academic teachers, disciples honor their spiritual gurus, and everyone pays respect to those who have guided them in life.

JUNE 17-20, 2026 - ANNUAL BRAHMOTSAVAM
Dates: Wednesday-Saturday, June 17-20, 2026
Temple Celebration: GRANDEST TEMPLE FESTIVAL OF THE YEAR
SIGNIFICANCE:
Annual Brahmotsavam is the most important and elaborate festival of the temple. "Brahmotsavam" means "festival of Brahma" - considered so sacred that even Lord Brahma would want to attend. This multi-day celebration honors Lord Venkateswara with elaborate rituals, processions, and sevas.
JUNE 17TH - ANKURARPANAM:
Date: Wednesday, June 17, 2026
Tithi: Chaturthi/Panchami
Event: Ceremonial beginning of Brahmotsavam
SIGNIFICANCE OF ANKURARPANAM:
Ceremonial planting of nine types of grains (navadhanya) in earthen pots filled with soil. The sprouting of seeds represents prosperity, divine blessings, and the growth of devotion. This ritual marks the auspicious beginning of the festival.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Planting ceremony with Vedic chants
- Kalasa sthapana (installation of sacred pots)
- Special prayers for successful completion of Brahmotsavam
- Temple decorations begin
JUNE 18TH-19TH - MAIN BRAHMOTSAVAM DAYS:
Dates: Thursday-Friday, June 18-19, 2026
Event: Peak celebration days with multiple sevas
DAILY SCHEDULE (Both Days):
- Early Morning: Suprabhatam and special abhishekams
- Morning: Snapana Thirumanjanam (sacred bath ceremony)
- Midday: Various Vahana Sevas (deity mounted on different vehicles)
- Evening: Grand processions
VAHANA SEVAS (Vehicle Processions):
- Garuda Vahanam (divine eagle mount)
- Hanumantha Vahanam (Lord Hanuman vehicle)
- Simha Vahanam (lion vehicle)
- Gaja Vahanam (elephant mount)
- Surya Prabha Vahanam (sun chariot)
- And other traditional vehicles
Each vahana has spiritual significance and represents different aspects of divine protection and blessings.
JUNE 20TH - CHAKRA SNANAM / DWAJAVAROHANAM:
Date: Saturday, June 20, 2026
Event: Grand conclusion of Brahmotsavam
CHAKRA SNANAM SIGNIFICANCE:

The final and most important day of Brahmotsavam. "Chakra Snanam" involves the ceremonial bathing of Sudarshana Chakra (Lord Vishnu's divine discus) in sacred waters. This ritual symbolizes the cleansing of sins and bestowing of divine blessings.
DWAJAVAROHANAM:
Ceremonial lowering of the temple flag (Dhwaja), marking the official conclusion of the festival.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Sacred bath of Sudarshana Chakra
- Final grand procession
- Lowering of temple flag with Vedic chants
- Distribution of blessed water (theertham)
- Grand prasadam distribution
- Cultural programs concluding
OVERALL BRAHMOTSAVAM FEATURES:
- Continuous special poojas for four days
- Elaborate deity decorations (alankaram)
- Traditional music and dance performances
- Special prasadam daily
- Community participation and gatherings
- Spiritual discourses
DEVOTEE PARTICIPATION:
Devotees can sponsor:
- Daily sevas and abhishekams
- Vahana sevas
- Annadanam (food offerings)
- Cultural programs
- Decorations and garlands
Contact temple office for sponsorship details

Date: Thursday, March 19, 2026
Tithi: Dwitiya
Also Known As: Yugadi, Telugu/Kannada New Year
Also on this day: Sri Andal Abhishekam, Sri Varaha Jayanti
Temple Celebration: Grand New Year celebration
SIGNIFICANCE:
Ugadi marks the New Year for people in Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, and Karnataka. "Ugadi" comes from "Yuga" (age) and "Adi" (beginning), meaning "the beginning of a new age." This year is "Parabhava Naama Samvatsara." Ugadi is the official beginning of the Hindu lunar calendar year.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Ugadi Pachadi preparation (six tastes representing life's experiences)
- Panchan Shravanam (reading of the year's predictions)
- House cleaning and decorations
- Mango leaf torans on doorways
- New clothes
- Special prayers and poojas
- Family gatherings and feast
UGADI PACHADI - Six Tastes:
1. Sweet (jaggery) - Happiness
2. Sour (tamarind) - Challenges
3. Bitter (neem) - Sadness
4. Salty (salt) - Interests/Desires
5. Spicy (chili) - Anger/Passion
6. Astringent (raw mango) - Surprise
SRI VARAHA JAYANTI:
Also celebrated on Ugadi - birthday of Lord Varaha (boar incarnation of Vishnu who rescued Earth from the cosmic ocean).

MARCH 26, 2026 - SRI RAMA NAVAMI
Date: Thursday, March 26, 2026
Tithi: Navami
Nakshatra: Punarvasu
Temple Celebration: Grand celebration with special rituals
SIGNIFICANCE:
Sri Rama Navami celebrates the birthday of Lord Rama, the seventh avatar of Lord Vishnu and the hero of the epic Ramayana. Lord Rama was born in Ayodhya to King Dasharatha and Queen Kausalya on the ninth day (Navami) of Chaitra month during bright fortnight (Sukla Paksha).
CELEBRATIONS:
- Reading of Ramayana (Rama Katha)
- Rama Pattabhishekam (coronation ceremony)
- Rama Kalyanam (divine wedding - on following days)
- Nine-day celebration (Rama Navami falls on 9th day)
- Special abhishekam and alankaram to Sri Rama
- Bhajan and kirtan
- Processions with Rama's idol
- Distribution of panakam (jaggery drink) and prasadam
SPIRITUAL SIGNIFICANCE:
- Embodiment of dharma (righteousness)
- Victory of good over evil
- Ideal king, son, brother, and husband
- Following the path of truth and duty
OBSERVANCES:
- Fasting (complete or partial)
- Recitation of Rama Nama
- Reading Sundara Kanda from Ramayana
- Charity and feeding the poor

MARCH 28, 2026 - SRI SITARAMA KALYANAM
Date: Saturday, March 28, 2026
Tithi: Dwadasi
Also on this day: Sri Hanuman Abhishekam
Temple Celebration: Divine wedding ceremony
SIGNIFICANCE:
Sri Sitarama Kalyanam celebrates the divine wedding of Lord Rama and Goddess Sita. The marriage is re-enacted with great devotion and traditional rituals, symbolizing the perfect union and ideal relationship.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Wedding ceremony re-enactment
- Special decorations and mandapam
- Traditional wedding rituals
- Offering of sarees and ornaments
- Special alankaram to deities
- Distribution of wedding prasadam
- Cultural programs depicting Ramayana scenes
SPIRITUAL MESSAGE:
The marriage of Rama and Sita represents the union of dharma (righteousness) and devotion, serving as an ideal for married life.

MARCH 31, 2026 - PANGUNI UTTARAM
Date: Tuesday, March 31, 2026
Tithi: Purnima (approaching)
Nakshatra: Uttaraphalguni
Temple Celebration: Special deity weddings and celebrations
SIGNIFICANCE:
Panguni Uttaram is a significant Tamil festival associated with the Uttaraphalguni nakshatra in the Tamil month of Panguni (March-April). It celebrates divine weddings, particularly:
- Marriage of Goddess Parvati to Lord Shiva
- Marriage of Lord Murugan to Goddess Deivayanai
- Various other divine kalyanams
CELEBRATIONS:
- Temple processions with decorated deities
- Re-enactment of divine marriages
- Special alankaram and decorations
- Offering of garlands and flowers
- Cultural performances
- Community feasts
SPIRITUAL SIGNIFICANCE:
Panguni Uttaram is considered highly auspicious for weddings and new beginnings. The day signifies divine blessings for marital harmony and prosperity.

MAY 1, 2026 - SRI KURMA JAYANTI / SRI ANNAMACHARYA JAYANTI
Date: Friday, May 1, 2026
Tithi: Purnima (Full Moon)
Temple Celebration: Special poojas for both occasions
SRI KURMA JAYANTI SIGNIFICANCE:
Celebrates the birthday of Lord Kurma (Tortoise Avatar), the second incarnation of Lord Vishnu. During Samudra Manthan (churning of the ocean), Lord Vishnu took the form of a giant tortoise to support Mount Mandara on his back, enabling the churning to continue.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Special Kurma abhishekam
- Reading of Kurma Purana
- Recitation of Dashavatara stotra
- Offering special prasadam
SRI ANNAMACHARYA JAYANTI SIGNIFICANCE:
Birth anniversary of Sri Tallapaka Annamacharya (1408-1503), the great composer of devotional songs dedicated to Lord Venkateswara. He composed over 32,000 sankirtanas (devotional songs) in Telugu.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Singing of Annamacharya sankirtanas
- Musical programs
- Lectures on Annamacharya's life and works
- Special prayers at Venkateswara temples

MAY 11, 2026 - SRI HANUMAN JAYANTI
Date: Monday, May 11, 2026
Tithi: Dasami
Temple Celebration: Grand Hanuman Jayanti celebration
SIGNIFICANCE:
Sri Hanuman Jayanti celebrates the birthday of Lord Hanuman, the devoted servant of Lord Rama and epitome of strength, devotion, and celibacy. Hanuman played a crucial role in the Ramayana, helping Lord Rama rescue Sita from Ravana.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Special Hanuman abhishekam
- Recitation of Hanuman Chalisa (108 times by devotees)
- Reading of Sundara Kanda
- Offering of sindoor, jasmine oil, besan laddoos
- All-day kirtan and bhajan
- Langur feeding (where applicable)
- Distribution of prasadam
SPIRITUAL SIGNIFICANCE:
- Symbol of devotion and service
- Remover of obstacles
- Giver of strength and courage
- Protector from evil
OBSERVANCES:
Devotees fast and visit Hanuman temples. Many read or listen to the entire Sundara Kanda from Ramayana.

MAY 16, 2026 - SRI SANISCHARA JAYANTI
Date: Saturday, May 16, 2026
Tithi: Amavasya (New Moon)
Also on this day: Sri Mahalakshmi Abhishekam
Temple Celebration: Special Shani pooja
SIGNIFICANCE:
Sri Sanischara (Shani) Jayanti celebrates the birth of Lord Shani, the deity of planet Saturn. Shani is considered the giver of justice who rewards or punishes based on one's karma.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Shani pooja and abhishekam
- Offering of black sesame seeds, mustard oil
- Wearing black or dark blue clothes
- Lighting oil lamps
- Recitation of Shani mantras
- Charity to the needy
OBSERVANCES:
Devotees pray for relief from Shani dosha and planetary afflictions. This is especially important for those in Sade Sati period.

MAY 29, 2026 - NAMMAZHWAR TIRUNAKSHATRAM
Date: Friday, May 29, 2026
Tithi: Chaturdasi
Temple Celebration: Special prayers honoring Nammazhwar
SIGNIFICANCE:
Nammazhwar Tirunakshatram celebrates the birth star of Nammazhwar (Sadagopan), one of the twelve Alvars (Vaishnava saint poets) and considered the greatest among them. He composed Thiruvaimozhi, which is revered as the "Tamil Veda."
CONTRIBUTIONS:
- Composed 1,296 verses in Tamil
- Thiruvaimozhi (1,000 verses)
- Thiruvasiriyam (7 verses)
- Periya Thiruvandhadhi (87 verses)
- Composed without formal education, in divine ecstasy
CELEBRATIONS:
- Recitation of Thiruvaimozhi
- Special archana to Nammazhwar
- Lectures on Alwar's philosophy
- Cultural programs

MAY 30, 2026 - SRI SATYANARAYANA SWAMY POOJA & VRATHAM
Date: Saturday, May 30, 2026
Tithi: Purnima (Full Moon) - Second Purnima of May due to Adhika Maasa
Temple Celebration: Special pooja and vratam at 6:30 PM
SPECIAL NOTE:
May 2026 has TWO Purnimas due to Adhika Jyeshta Maasa (leap month). This is the second Purnima of the month.

ADHIKA MAASA NOTE:
May 16 - June 13, 2026 is Adhika Jyeshta Maasa (extra/leap month). During this period:
- Regular festivals are generally not celebrated
- Auspicious ceremonies like weddings are avoided
- Good time for spiritual practices, meditation, and charity
- Focus on devotional activities
NOVEMBER 2026 EVENTS & FESTIVALS

NOVEMBER 1, 2026 - DAYLIGHT SAVING TIME ENDS
Date: Sunday, November 1, 2026
Also on this day: Sri Siva Abhishekam
Note: Clocks fall back one hour at 2:00 AM

NOVEMBER 7, 2026 - NARAKA CHATURDASI
Date: Saturday, November 7, 2026
Tithi: Chaturdasi (one day before Deepavali)
Also on this day: Sri Venkateswara Abhishekam
Temple Celebration: Pre-Deepavali observances
SIGNIFICANCE:
Naraka Chaturdasi, also called Choti Diwali or Roop Chaturdashi, is celebrated one day before Deepavali. It commemorates Lord Krishna's victory over the demon Narakasura, who had imprisoned 16,100 daughters of gods and saints.
LEGEND:
Narakasura, son of Mother Earth, became arrogant with power and terrorized the three worlds. Lord Krishna, with his consort Satyabhama, killed Narakasura and freed the imprisoned princesses. Before dying, Narakasura requested that his death be celebrated, hence this festival.
OBSERVANCES:
- Abhyanga Snanam (oil bath) before sunrise
- Applying ubtan (herbal paste)
- Lighting oil lamps in the evening
- Bursting small firecrackers
- Preparing special sweets
- Cleaning and decorating homes
SPIRITUAL SIGNIFICANCE:
- Victory of light over darkness
- Destruction of ego and evil
- Purification before Deepavali

NOVEMBER 8, 2026 - DEEPAVALI (DIWALI)
Date: Sunday, November 8, 2026
Tithi: Amavasya (New Moon)
Also Known As: Diwali, Festival of Lights
Also on this day: Sri Vijaya Ganapathi / Murugan Abhishekam
Temple Celebration: Grand celebration with lakhs of lights
SIGNIFICANCE:
Deepavali, the "Festival of Lights," is the most widely celebrated Hindu festival. It symbolizes the victory of light over darkness, good over evil, and knowledge over ignorance. The festival is celebrated across India and by Hindus worldwide with different regional stories and customs.
PRIMARY LEGENDS:
1. North India: Lord Rama's return to Ayodhya after 14 years of exile and defeating Ravana
2. South India: Lord Krishna's victory over demon Narakasura
3. West India: Lord Vishnu sending demon king Bali to netherworld
4. Jainism: Lord Mahavira attaining nirvana
5. Sikhism: Release of Guru Hargobind Ji from imprisonment
GODDESS LAKSHMI:
Deepavali is especially dedicated to Goddess Lakshmi, deity of wealth and prosperity. This is the main Lakshmi Puja day of the year.
PREPARATIONS:
- Thorough cleaning of homes and workplaces
- Decorating with rangoli/kolam
- Whitewashing and painting
- Shopping for new clothes
- Buying gold and silver
- Preparing special sweets
CELEBRATIONS:
- Lakshmi Puja in evening (most auspicious time)
- Lighting diyas (oil lamps) throughout home
- Decorating with electric lights
- Bursting firecrackers (in moderation)
- Exchanging gifts and sweets
- Wearing new clothes
- Family gatherings and feast
- Playing cards (traditional)
- Business community: closing old account books, opening new ones
SPIRITUAL OBSERVANCES:
- Invoke Goddess Lakshmi for prosperity
- Light lamps to dispel darkness/ignorance
- Offer prayers for family well-being
- Charity to the less fortunate
- Feeding the poor
FIVE DAYS OF DIWALI (Extended Celebration):
Though Deepavali is primarily one day, traditionally it's celebrated over five days:
- Day 1: Dhanteras (2 days before)

- Day 2: Naraka Chaturdasi/Choti Diwali (1 day before)
- Day 3: Deepavali/Lakshmi Puja (Main day - Nov 8)
- Day 4: Govardhan Puja/Annakut (1 day after)
- Day 5: Bhai Dooj (2 days after)
IMPORTANT RITUALS:
- Cleaning and purifying the home
- Creating rangoli at entrance
- Lighting 108 or 365 diyas
- Offering sweets to Lakshmi
- Keeping doors/windows open for Lakshmi's entry
- New account books for businesses
ECO-FRIENDLY CELEBRATION:
- Using clay diyas instead of electric lights when possible
- Avoiding loud and polluting firecrackers
- Choosing green crackers
- Celebrating responsibly

NOVEMBER 12, 2026 - NAGA CHATURTHI (NAGULA CHAVITI)
Date: Thursday, November 12, 2026
Tithi: Chaturthi
Also on this day: Sri Manavala Mahamuni Tirunakshatram
Temple Celebration: Serpent worship observances
SIGNIFICANCE:
Naga Chaturthi, also called Nagula Chaviti in Telugu, is a festival dedicated to serpent worship. It's particularly important in Andhra Pradesh and Telangana, where women fast and pray for the well-being of their brothers and male family members.
LEGEND:
Based on the story of a woman whose brothers were killed by snake bite. Through devotion and prayers, she brought them back to life.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Women observe fasting
- Worship of snake idols or images
- Drawing snake designs with turmeric and kumkum
- Offering milk and eggs (traditional)
- Prayers for protection from snake bites
- Sisters praying for brothers' welfare
SRI MANAVALA MAHAMUNI TIRUNAKSHATRAM:
Birth star of Manavala Mamuni, important Sri Vaishnava acharya of the 15th century.

NOVEMBER 14, 2026 - SRI VISHVAKSENA JAYANTI / SRI SKANDA SHASHTI
Date: Saturday, November 14, 2026
Tithi: Panchami/Shashti
Also on this day: Sri Venkateswara Kalyanam
Temple Celebration: Dual celebration
SRI VISHVAKSENA JAYANTI SIGNIFICANCE:
Birthday of Vishvaksena, the commander-in-chief of Lord Vishnu's army. In Sri Vaishnavism, Vishvaksena is worshiped as the remover of obstacles before beginning any pooja or ritual.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Special Vishvaksena pooja
- Prayers before main temple rituals
- Seeking blessings for obstacle-free worship
SRI SKANDA SHASHTI SIGNIFICANCE:
Six-day festival culminating on Shashti (6th day), dedicated to Lord Murugan (Skanda). Celebrates Murugan's victory over the demon Surapadman.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Kavadi (burden) carrying by devotees
- Fasting for six days
- Reading Skanda Purana
- Vel (spear) worship
- Temple processions

NOVEMBER 21, 2026 - SRI TULASI KALYANAM
Date: Saturday, November 21, 2026
Tithi: Trayodasi/Dwadasi
Also on this day: Sri Mahalakshmi Abhishekam
Temple Celebration: Divine wedding ceremony
SIGNIFICANCE:
Sri Tulasi Kalyanam celebrates the ceremonial wedding of the sacred Tulasi plant (holy basil) to Lord Vishnu or his Shaligrama form. This festival marks the end of the monsoon season and the beginning of the Hindu wedding season.
LEGEND:
Based on the story of Vrinda (Tulasi), a devoted wife whose virtue protected her demon husband Jalandhar. After deception led to his death, she became the Tulasi plant and was wed to Lord Vishnu.
SPIRITUAL SIGNIFICANCE:
- Tulasi is considered the most sacred plant in Hinduism
- Represents devotion and purity
- Marriage to Vishnu symbolizes union of devotee with divine
- After this day, Hindu weddings can be performed (before Dev Uthani Ekadasi)
CELEBRATIONS:
- Installing Tulasi Vrindavan (sacred enclosure)
- Decorating Tulasi plant as bride
- Shaligrama stone as groom
- Traditional wedding rituals
- Circumambulation of Tulasi
- Offering of new clothes and jewelry
- Lighting lamps around Tulasi
- Distribution of prasadam
OBSERVANCES:
Women who observe fast for husband's longevity participate actively. This is also called Tulasi Vivah.

NOVEMBER 23, 2026 - KARTIKA PURNIMA / KARTIKA DEEPAM
Date: Monday, November 23, 2026
Tithi: Purnima (Full Moon)
Also on this day: Kartika Somavara Siva Abhishekam, Sri Satyanarayana Pooja
Temple Celebration: Festival of lights for Lord Shiva
SIGNIFICANCE:
Kartika Purnima is the full moon day of Kartika month, one of the most sacred days in Hindu calendar. Also called Tripuri Purnima, it celebrates multiple divine events.
KARTIKA DEEPAM SIGNIFICANCE:
Festival of lighting lamps, especially significant in South India where it celebrates Lord Shiva appearing as an endless pillar of light (Jyoti). At Tiruvannamalai, Tamil Nadu, a huge lamp is lit atop Arunachala Hill.
MYTHOLOGICAL EVENTS ON THIS DAY:
- Lord Shiva destroyed three demon cities (Tripura)
- Birth of Kartikeya (Murugan)
- Matsya Avatar of Vishnu appeared
- Lord Vishnu's Prabodhini Ekadasi (waking from yoga nidra - occurs day before)
CELEBRATIONS:
- Lighting lamps throughout home and temples
- Special Siva pooja
- Kartika Snanam (holy bath)
- Charity and donations (highly meritorious)
- Offering of lamps in temples
- Feeding the poor
- Pilgrimage to sacred rivers
KARTIKA MAASA IMPORTANCE:
The entire month of Kartika (October-November) is sacred. Throughout this month:
- Daily lamp offerings
- Fasting on Ekadasis
- Special Somavara (Monday) Siva worship
- Reading Bhagavad Gita or Bhagavatam
- Extra spiritual practices

NOVEMBER 26, 2026 - THANKSGIVING DAY
Date: Thursday, November 26, 2026
Tithi: Chaturthi
Temple Hours: Open for prayers

KARTIKA SOMAVARA (MONDAYS IN KARTIKA):
Throughout November 2026: Special Siva Abhishekams on Mondays
- November 9, 16, 23, 30
Kartika Somavara (Mondays in Kartika month) are specially auspicious for Lord Shiva worship. Special Siva Abhishekams performed at the temple.

OCTOBER 2026 EVENTS & FESTIVALS

OCTOBER 10, 2026 - MAHALAYA AMAVASYA
Date: Saturday, October 10, 2026
Tithi: Amavasya (New Moon)
Also on this day: Sri Venkateswara Kalyanam
Temple Celebration: Ancestral rites and Navaratri beginning
SIGNIFICANCE:
Mahalaya Amavasya is the most important day of Pitru Paksha (fortnight for ancestors). It marks the culmination of the fifteen-day period when Hindus pay homage to their departed ancestors through Shraddha ceremonies. This Amavasya also marks the beginning of Navaratri celebrations.
PITRU PAKSHA (MAHALAYA PAKSHA):
The fifteen days from September 27 to October 10 are dedicated to performing last rites and offering tarpana (water offerings) to ancestors.
OBSERVANCES:
- Tarpana (water offering) to ancestors
- Shraddha ceremony with family priest
- Offering of rice balls (pinda) and food
- Charity and feeding Brahmins
- Prayers for peace of departed souls
- Feeding crows (believed to be ancestors' representatives)
SPIRITUAL SIGNIFICANCE:
- Expressing gratitude to ancestors
- Seeking blessings from forefathers
- Completing family duties (dharma)
- Removing ancestral curses (Pitru dosha)
BEGINNING OF NAVARATRI:
After Pitru Paksha ends with Mahalaya Amavasya, Navaratri begins the next day, marking transition from honoring ancestors to celebrating Divine Mother.

OCTOBER 11-20, 2026 - NAVARATRI / DURGA PUJA
Dates: Sunday-Tuesday, October 11-20, 2026
Also Known As: Sarannavaratri, Sharad Navaratri, Durgotsav
Temple Celebration: Nine-day grand festival of Goddess Durga
SIGNIFICANCE:
Navaratri ("Nine Nights") is one of the most important Hindu festivals, celebrating the Divine Mother in her various forms. Sharad Navaratri (autumn) is the most widely celebrated of the four Navaratris.
THEME OF NINE DAYS:
Days 1-3: Goddess Durga (Destroyer of Evil)
- Symbolizes power and strength
- Destroys negative forces
Days 4-6: Goddess Lakshmi (Bestower of Wealth)
- Symbolizes prosperity and abundance
- Grants material and spiritual wealth
Days 7-9: Goddess Saraswati (Giver of Knowledge)
- Symbolizes wisdom and arts
- Grants knowledge and enlightenment
OCTOBER 11TH (Day 1) - GHATASTHAPANA:
Ceremonial installation of sacred pot (kalash) marking Navaratri's beginning.
OCTOBER 12TH-15TH (Days 2-5):
- Daily goddess worship
- Fasting (varies by tradition)
- Recitation of Devi Mahatmyam
- Evening aarti and bhajans
OCTOBER 16TH (Day 6) - SARASWATI PUJA:
Friday, October 16, 2026
Tithi: Shashti/Saptami
Also on this day: Sri Andal Abhishekam
SARASWATI PUJA SIGNIFICANCE:
Sixth day dedicated to Goddess Saraswati. Books, musical instruments, and tools of learning are worshiped.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Placing books near goddess
- Students seek blessings
- Initiation into learning for children
- Prayers for knowledge and wisdom
- Wearing yellow (auspicious color)
OCTOBER 17TH (Day 7):
Saturday, October 17, 2026
Also on this day: Sri Mahalakshmi Abhishekam
OCTOBER 18TH (Day 8) - DURGASHTAMI:
Sunday, October 18, 2026
Tithi: Ashtami/Navami
Also on this day: Sri Shirdi Sai Baba / Raghavendra Swamy Abhishekam
DURGASHTAMI SIGNIFICANCE:
Eighth day - most important day for Goddess Durga worship. Commemorates Durga's fierce battle with demons.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Special Durga abhishekam
- Kumari Puja (worship of young girls as manifestations of goddess)

- Sandhi Puja (junction of Ashtami and Navami)
- Offering of special naivedyam
- All-day fasting by devotees
OCTOBER 19TH (Day 9) - MAHA NAVAMI / AYUDHA PUJA:
Monday, October 19, 2026
Tithi: Navami/Dasami
AYUDHA PUJA SIGNIFICANCE:
Ninth day dedicated to worshiping tools, instruments, and vehicles - all implements of livelihood. Particularly significant in South India.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Cleaning and decorating tools/vehicles
- Placing tools near goddess
- Special pooja for instruments
- Workers honor their equipment
- Farmers worship agricultural tools
- Artists worship their instruments
OCTOBER 20TH (Day 10) - VIJAYA DASAMI:
Tuesday, October 20, 2026
Tithi: Dasami/Ekadasi
VIJAYA DASAMI SIGNIFICANCE:
The climax of Navaratri celebrating:
1. Goddess Durga's victory over demon Mahishasura
2. Lord Rama's victory over Ravana (Dussehra)
Both symbolize triumph of good over evil.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Final grand pooja to goddess
- Visarjan (immersion) of Durga idols
- Ram Lila performances depicting Ramayana
- Burning of Ravana effigies
- Starting new ventures
- Vidyarambham (initiating children into learning)
- Seeking blessings for success
AUSPICIOUS ACTIVITIES:
Most favorable day for:
- Beginning education
- Starting new business
- Purchasing vehicles
- Launching new projects
- Any new beginnings

OCTOBER 25, 2026 - SRI SATYANARAYANA SWAMY POOJA & VRATHAM
Date: Sunday, October 25, 2026
Tithi: Prathama (after Purnima)
Temple Celebration: Special pooja and vratham at 6:30 PM
SEPTEMBER 2026 EVENTS & FESTIVALS

SEPTEMBER 4, 2026 - SRI KRISHNASHTAMI
Date: Friday, September 4, 2026
Tithi: Ashtami
Nakshatra: Rohini
Also Known As: Krishna Janmashtami, Gokulashtami
Temple Celebration: Midnight celebration with special abhishekam
SIGNIFICANCE:
Sri Krishnashtami celebrates the birth of Lord Krishna, the eighth avatar of Lord Vishnu. Krishna was born at midnight in Mathura prison to Devaki and Vasudeva, to destroy the tyrant king Kamsa and establish dharma.
STORY:
Krishna's birth was prophesied to end Kamsa's tyrannical rule. Born in prison at midnight, baby Krishna was miraculously transported to Gokul by Vasudeva across the flooded Yamuna river, where he was raised by Yashoda and Nanda.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Fasting until midnight (birth time)
- Decorating cradle (jhula) for baby Krishna
- Midnight abhishekam and pooja
- Dahi Handi (pot-breaking) celebrations
- Singing Krishna bhajans and devotional songs
- Enacting episodes from Krishna's life (Rasa Leela)
- Offering Krishna's favorite foods (butter, milk sweets)
- Breaking fast after midnight pooja
- Cultural programs
SPIRITUAL SIGNIFICANCE:
- Birth of divine consciousness
- Victory of good over evil
- Message of Bhagavad Gita (Krishna's teachings)
- Path of devotion and righteousness

SEPTEMBER 14, 2026 - SRI VINAYAKA CHATURTHI
Date: Monday, September 14, 2026
Tithi: Panchami (Chaturthi before it)
Also Known As: Ganesh Chaturthi, Vinayagar Chaturthi
Temple Celebration: Ten-day grand festival begins
SIGNIFICANCE:
Sri Vinayaka Chaturthi celebrates the birthday of Lord Ganesha, the elephant-headed deity who is the remover of obstacles and lord of beginnings. This is one of the most widely celebrated Hindu festivals.
LEGEND:
Goddess Parvati created Ganesha from turmeric paste to guard her while bathing. When Lord Shiva unknowingly beheaded him, Parvati's grief led Shiva to revive him with an elephant's head.
CELEBRATIONS - DAY 1 (Installation):
- Installing Ganesha idol (clay/eco-friendly preferred)
- Pranapratishtha (invoking life into the idol)
- Elaborate decorations
- Special poojas throughout the day
- Offering modaks (Ganesha's favorite sweet)
- Chanting Ganesha mantras
- Community gatherings
DAYS 2-10:
- Daily poojas and aarti
- Cultural programs
- Devotional singing
- Offering different naivedyam each day
- Public celebrations with large Ganesha idols
IMPORTANT OFFERINGS:
- Modak (sweet dumplings)
- Durva grass (sacred to Ganesha)
- Red flowers
- Coconuts
- Fruits

SEPTEMBER 19, 2026 - SRI VINAYAKA NIMAJJANAM
Date: Saturday, September 19, 2026
Tithi: Dasami
Also Known As: Ganesh Visarjan, Ganpati Visarjan
Also on this day: Sri Hanuman Abhishekam
Temple Celebration: Immersion ceremony concluding festival
SIGNIFICANCE:
Vinayaka Nimajjanam marks the ceremonial immersion of Lord Ganesha's idol, concluding the ten-day Ganesh Chaturthi celebrations. The immersion symbolizes Ganesha's return to his celestial abode, taking away the obstacles and misfortunes of devotees.
PROCESSION:
- Grand processions with decorated Ganesha idols
- Dancing and singing "Ganapati Bappa Morya"
- Playing of drums and musical instruments
- Community participation in large numbers
- Emotional farewell to the beloved deity
IMMERSION RITUAL:
- Final pooja and aarti before immersion
- Circumambulation of the idol
- Prayers for Ganesha's return next year
- Immersion in water bodies (rivers, lakes, sea)
- Chanting "Ganapati Bappa Morya, Purchya Varshi Laukar Ya" 
  (Come back soon next year)
SPIRITUAL MESSAGE:
- Impermanence of material forms
- Cycle of creation and dissolution
- Letting go with devotion
- Promise of renewal
ECO-FRIENDLY PRACTICE:
Encouragement to use clay idols and designated immersion tanks to protect the environment.

SEPTEMBER 22, 2026 - SRI VENKATESWARA SWAMY JAYANTI / SRI VEDANTA DESIKAR TIRUNAKSHATRAM
Date: Tuesday, September 22, 2026
Tithi: Trayodasi
Nakshatra: Satabhisha
Also on this day: Sri Venkateswara Abhishekam
Temple Celebration: Double celebration
SRI VENKATESWARA SWAMY JAYANTI SIGNIFICANCE:
Birthday of Lord Venkateswara (Balaji), the presiding deity of Tirumala temple and the most visited Hindu temple in the world. Lord Venkateswara is a form of Lord Vishnu.
CELEBRATIONS:
- Grand abhishekam with various sacred items
- Special alankaram (decoration)
- Reading of Venkateswara Mahatmyam
- Offering of laddus (Tirupati's famous prasadam)
- All-day bhajan and kirtan
- Distribution of special prasadam
- Cultural programs
SRI VEDANTA DESIKAR TIRUNAKSHATRAM:
Birth star of Sri Vedanta Desika (1268-1369), great Vaishnava philosopher, poet, and devotee. He composed numerous works in Sanskrit and Tamil.
CONTRIBUTIONS:
- Wrote over 100 works on philosophy, poetry, and devotion
- Composed beautiful stotras (hymns)
- Defended and strengthened Sri Vaishnavism
- Known for his brilliance and devotion

SEPTEMBER 24-27, 2026 - PAVITROTSAVAM
Dates: Thursday-Sunday, September 24-27, 2026
Temple Celebration: Four-day purification festival
SIGNIFICANCE:
Pavitrotsavam is an important temple festival focused on purification and spiritual renewal. "Pavitra" means sacred or pure. During this festival, sacred threads (pavitrams) are ceremonially prepared and offered to the deities.
SEPTEMBER 24TH - ANKURARPANAM:
Ceremonial planting of seeds marking the festival's beginning.
SEPTEMBER 25TH - PAVITRA SAMARPANA / PAVITROTSAVAM BEGINS:
- Preparation of sacred threads with mantras
- Offering pavitrams to all deities
- Special abhishekams and decorations
- Purification rituals
CELEBRATIONS DURING PAVITROTSAVAM:
- Daily special poojas
- Vahana sevas (processions)
- Cultural programs
- Distribution of pavitram to devotees
- Spiritual discourses
SEPTEMBER 27TH - SHANTI KALYANAM / PAVITROTSAVAM ENDS:
- Divine wedding ceremony (Shanti Kalyanam)
- Final grand procession
- Conclusion rituals
- Distribution of prasadam
Also on September 27th: MAHALAYA (PITRU) PAKSHAM BEGINS
The fifteen-day period for ancestral rites starts, continuing until Mahalaya Amavasya (October 10).

SPECIAL AMAVASYA OBSERVANCES:

Maha Sivaratri (February 16):
- Most important festival dedicated to Lord Shiva
- Night-long vigil and fasting observed
- Special poojas and abhishekams performed

Mahalaya Amavasya (October 10):
- Marks the end of Pitru Paksham (fortnight for ancestral offerings)
- Highly auspicious for Tarpana (offerings to ancestors)
- Beginning of Navaratri/Durga Puja season

Deepavali/Diwali (November 8):
- Festival of Lights
- Most celebrated Hindu festival
- Preceded by Naraka Chaturdasi on November 7

Sri Sanischara Jayanti (May 16):
- Birth anniversary of Lord Shani (Saturn deity)
- Special prayers for Shani Dev

PITRU PAKSHAM 2026:
The fifteen-day period for ancestral rites begins after the Purnima in September and ends on Mahalaya Amavasya (October 10, 2026). During this period, Hindus pay homage to their ancestors through Shraddha ceremonies.
